title: Chinese Government provides grant for establishment of Confucius Institute at University of Lagos
description: In 2008, Chinese officials and University of Lagos staff signed a grant agreement to establish a Confucius Institute at the University of Lagos (in collaboration with the Beijing Institute of Technology). The Confucius Institute at University of Lagos began its operations on May 20, 2009. An official opening ceremony took place on October 16, 2009.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for establishment of Confucius Institute at University of Lagos

# Description
In 2008, Chinese officials and University of Lagos staff signed a grant agreement to establish a Confucius Institute at the University of Lagos (in collaboration with the Beijing Institute of Technology). The Confucius Institute at University of Lagos began its operations on May 20, 2009. An official opening ceremony took place on October 16, 2009.
justification: Project focuses on educational and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute for education and cultural exchange

title: China Eximbank contributes $39.37 million of debt financing for Magboro Steel Mill Project (Linked to Project ID#60922)
description: On June 24, 2008, a syndicate of banks (including China Eximbank and Citigroup) signed a $137.79 million loan agreement with WEMPCO Steel Mill Co Ltd — a special purpose vehicle (SPV)— for the Magboro Steel Mill Project. The loan has a 7 year maturity (final maturity date: June 24, 2015), China Eximbank contributed $39.7 million to the loan and Citigroup contributed $98.42 million to the loan. On the same day, WEMPCO Steel Mill Co Ltd secured an $59.05 million loan from Zenith Bank and Access Bank for the Magboro Steel Mill Project. Wempco Group (Western Metal Products Company, a Chinese owned company) also make a $64.96 million equity contribution for the same project (see Project ID#60922).   The Magboro Steel Mill Project involved the installation of a 50MW generator set at the Magboro factory in order to convert imported Hot Rolled Steel coil into Cold Rolled Steel sheets using a continuous steel cold rolling process. China 20MCC Construction Co., Ltd. (20MCC) was the contractor responsible for implementation.   The project officially commenced on June 15, 2011 and it was completed on November 30, 2012. Then, an official commissioning ceremony took place on on April 19, 2013. The Magboro factory, which is located in Magboro within Ogun State, now has a production capacity of 700,000 metric tons a year.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the 900mm Cold-rolling Project. The Chinese project title is 尼日利亚董氏集团900毫米冷轧工程 or 900毫米冷轧线项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank contributes $39.37 million of debt financing for Magboro Steel Mill Project (Linked to Project ID#60922)

# Description
On June 24, 2008, a syndicate of banks (including China Eximbank and Citigroup) signed a $137.79 million loan agreement with WEMPCO Steel Mill Co Ltd — a special purpose vehicle (SPV)— for the Magboro Steel Mill Project. The loan has a 7 year maturity (final maturity date: June 24, 2015), China Eximbank contributed $39.7 million to the loan and Citigroup contributed $98.42 million to the loan. On the same day, WEMPCO Steel Mill Co Ltd secured an $59.05 million loan from Zenith Bank and Access Bank for the Magboro Steel Mill Project. Wempco Group (Western Metal Products Company, a Chinese owned company) also make a $64.96 million equity contribution for the same project (see Project ID#60922).   The Magboro Steel Mill Project involved the installation of a 50MW generator set at the Magboro factory in order to convert imported Hot Rolled Steel coil into Cold Rolled Steel sheets using a continuous steel cold rolling process. China 20MCC Construction Co., Ltd. (20MCC) was the contractor responsible for implementation.   The project officially commenced on June 15, 2011 and it was completed on November 30, 2012. Then, an official commissioning ceremony took place on on April 19, 2013. The Magboro factory, which is located in Magboro within Ogun State, now has a production capacity of 700,000 metric tons a year.
justification: Steel production is a high-emission industry, but the project includes energy generation and efficiency improvements
evidence: Installation of 50MW generator set, cold rolling process, 700,000 metric tons annual production capacity

title: China Eximbank provides $6.7 million loan for Textile Industrial Park Construction Project
description: In 2008, China Eximbank provided a $6.7 million loan to the Yuemei Group (or Zhejiang Yuemei Group Co., Ltd.) for the construction of a textile industrial park in Nigeria. In 2007 and 2008, the Yuemei Group invested more than $50 million to construct the Yuemei-Nigeria Textile Industry Park — China’s first overseas textile industrial park — with a complete production chain of spinning, weaving, embroidery, knitting, and garment making. The proceeds of the China Eximbank loan were used to support this investment. By 2009, five textile firms had moved into the industrial park and employed an estimated 1,000 local workers.   The original vision was to establish a textile cluster where different specialist textile production firms could co-locate. However, despite interest from Chinese textiles firms, only two firms ever came to invest in this cluster: Mawa, which specialized in textile dying and printing, and Jinmei, which specialized in embroidery. These investments were short-lived. Although Jinmei was operational from 2010 to 2011, its operations ceased soon after when demand for embroidered cloth plummeted. Mawa also ceased production in early 2014 due to short supplies of dyes. In February 2014, Mawa and Jinmei were evicted from the Yuemei Fabric Industrial Zone (YFIZ), and their assets were sold to new, non-Chinese buyers.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Yuemei-Nigeria Textile Industrial Park and the Yuemei Fabric Industrial Zone (YFIZ). The Chinese project title is 了尼日利亚纺织工业园区建设.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $6.7 million loan for Textile Industrial Park Construction Project

# Description
In 2008, China Eximbank provided a $6.7 million loan to the Yuemei Group (or Zhejiang Yuemei Group Co., Ltd.) for the construction of a textile industrial park in Nigeria. In 2007 and 2008, the Yuemei Group invested more than $50 million to construct the Yuemei-Nigeria Textile Industry Park — China’s first overseas textile industrial park — with a complete production chain of spinning, weaving, embroidery, knitting, and garment making. The proceeds of the China Eximbank loan were used to support this investment. By 2009, five textile firms had moved into the industrial park and employed an estimated 1,000 local workers.   The original vision was to establish a textile cluster where different specialist textile production firms could co-locate. However, despite interest from Chinese textiles firms, only two firms ever came to invest in this cluster: Mawa, which specialized in textile dying and printing, and Jinmei, which specialized in embroidery. These investments were short-lived. Although Jinmei was operational from 2010 to 2011, its operations ceased soon after when demand for embroidered cloth plummeted. Mawa also ceased production in early 2014 due to short supplies of dyes. In February 2014, Mawa and Jinmei were evicted from the Yuemei Fabric Industrial Zone (YFIZ), and their assets were sold to new, non-Chinese buyers.
justification: Project focuses on industrial park construction for textile manufacturing, which does not have a clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Textile industrial park construction, general manufacturing focus, no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China grant NZD 300,000 for asbestos reroofing in 2008
description: In 2008 the Chinese government granted 300,000 NZD (approx. 200,000 USD) to fund housing re-roofing after materials containing asbestos were stripped away from houses in Niue. According to page 20 of "China in the Pacific," as of 2011 the project had been marked as completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China grant NZD 300,000 for asbestos reroofing in 2008

# Description
In 2008 the Chinese government granted 300,000 NZD (approx. 200,000 USD) to fund housing re-roofing after materials containing asbestos were stripped away from houses in Niue. According to page 20 of "China in the Pacific," as of 2011 the project had been marked as completed.
justification: Project focuses on housing improvement and asbestos removal, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Housing re-roofing, asbestos removal, social infrastructure focus

title: China Donates Computers and Office Equipment to Niue in Advance of 2008 Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting
description: In 2008, the Chinese Government gave a gift of computers and office equipment including televisions, projectors, printers and photocopiers. However, the computer operating systems were not able to be used because they had not been configured appropriately for Niue. They were donated to help support the Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting in August 2008.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China Donates Computers and Office Equipment to Niue in Advance of 2008 Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting

# Description
In 2008, the Chinese Government gave a gift of computers and office equipment including televisions, projectors, printers and photocopiers. However, the computer operating systems were not able to be used because they had not been configured appropriately for Niue. They were donated to help support the Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting in August 2008.
justification: Project involves donation of office equipment for government and civil society purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Computers and office equipment donated for Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 1 million grant for human resources development
description: Between September 14th and 16th, 2008, during a state visit to (FYR) Macedonia by Chinese Deputy Prime Minister Zhang Deijang, China and Macedonia signed four agreements. According to statements made by Zhang Deijan, they deepen Chinese-Macedonian relations.   One of the agreements was signed between Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce, Yu Guangzhou, and Macedonian Minister of Economy, Fatmir Besimi on September 15th. The agreement was entitled “Exchange of Letters on Cooperation in Human Resources Development between the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Republic of Macedonia” (中华人民共和国和马其顿共和国政府关于人力资源开发合作的换文).  The agreement was associated with a CNY 1,000,000 Yuan grant for the purposes of developing Macedonian Human Resources. (Transaction amount documented in this project).   A second agreement, signed again by the Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce and Macedonian Minister of Economy, was entitled “Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation Between the Government of the People’s Republic of China and the Republic of Macedonia”  (中华人民共和国和马其顿共和国政府经济技术合作协定). According to the Macedonian Government’s official news outlet, MIA, the agreement is associated with a CNY 10,000,000 grant for realizing official development projects between the two governments (see project ID#42274). It was agreed the allocation of the CNY 10,000,000 would be decided by a later agreement.   A third agreement signed by Economic Counselor of the Chinese Embassy, Sun Livei,  and the Macedonian State Secretary of the Ministry of Economy, Krum Stojanov, was a memorandum of understanding (MoU) between Agency for Foreign Investments of the Republic of Macedonia and Investment Promotion Bureau within the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. The agreement was entitled Memorandum of Understanding on Promotion of Investment Promotion Agency of the Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China and the Foreign Investment Administration of the Republic of Macedonia” (中华人民共和国商务部投资促进事务局与马其顿共和国外资局促进谅解备忘录).   The fourth agreement was signed by the Macedonian Minister of Culture, Elizabeta Kanceska-Milevska, and the Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister, Wu Hongbo. The executive agreement was entitled “Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China and Culture of the Republic of Macedonia" Ministry of Culture 2008-2011 Implementation Plan for Cultural Cooperation” (中华人民共和国文化部和马其顿共和国文化部2008-2011年文化合作执行计划).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 1 million grant for human resources development

# Description
Between September 14th and 16th, 2008, during a state visit to (FYR) Macedonia by Chinese Deputy Prime Minister Zhang Deijang, China and Macedonia signed four agreements. According to statements made by Zhang Deijan, they deepen Chinese-Macedonian relations.   One of the agreements was signed between Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce, Yu Guangzhou, and Macedonian Minister of Economy, Fatmir Besimi on September 15th. The agreement was entitled “Exchange of Letters on Cooperation in Human Resources Development between the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Republic of Macedonia” (中华人民共和国和马其顿共和国政府关于人力资源开发合作的换文).  The agreement was associated with a CNY 1,000,000 Yuan grant for the purposes of developing Macedonian Human Resources. (Transaction amount documented in this project).   A second agreement, signed again by the Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce and Macedonian Minister of Economy, was entitled “Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation Between the Government of the People’s Republic of China and the Republic of Macedonia”  (中华人民共和国和马其顿共和国政府经济技术合作协定). According to the Macedonian Government’s official news outlet, MIA, the agreement is associated with a CNY 10,000,000 grant for realizing official development projects between the two governments (see project ID#42274). It was agreed the allocation of the CNY 10,000,000 would be decided by a later agreement.   A third agreement signed by Economic Counselor of the Chinese Embassy, Sun Livei,  and the Macedonian State Secretary of the Ministry of Economy, Krum Stojanov, was a memorandum of understanding (MoU) between Agency for Foreign Investments of the Republic of Macedonia and Investment Promotion Bureau within the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. The agreement was entitled Memorandum of Understanding on Promotion of Investment Promotion Agency of the Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China and the Foreign Investment Administration of the Republic of Macedonia” (中华人民共和国商务部投资促进事务局与马其顿共和国外资局促进谅解备忘录).   The fourth agreement was signed by the Macedonian Minister of Culture, Elizabeta Kanceska-Milevska, and the Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister, Wu Hongbo. The executive agreement was entitled “Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China and Culture of the Republic of Macedonia" Ministry of Culture 2008-2011 Implementation Plan for Cultural Cooperation” (中华人民共和国文化部和马其顿共和国文化部2008-2011年文化合作执行计划).
justification: Project focuses on human resources development and cultural cooperation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Grant for human resources development, cultural cooperation agreement, no energy or infrastructure components mentioned

title: China’s SAFE provides $500 million deposit loan to shore up Pakistan’s foreign exchange reserves in 2008
description: In June 2008, China’s State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) provided a $500 million deposit loan to State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) in order to shore up the country’s foreign exchange reserves. The loan carried the following terms: a 6-year (estimated) maturity and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (3.104% in June 2008) plus a 1% margin. The loan was repayable semi-annually. According to the SBP, the outstanding balance of this loan was $300 million on June 30, 2011, $200 million on June 30, 2012, and $100 million on June 30, 2013.
staff_comments: 1. The Fiscal Year 2013 Annual Report of SBP identifies ‘two long-term deposits of USD 500 million each received from the State Administration Foreign Exchange (SAFE) China in January 2009 (rolled-over in January 2013) and June 2012 carrying interest at six months LIBOR plus 100 bps and twelve months LIBOR plus 100 bps respectively, both payable semi-annually. These deposits of USD 500 million each have been set off against the rupee counterpart receivable from the Federal Government and have been covered under Ministry of Finance (MoF) Guarantees dated February 7, 2013 and June 29, 2012 whereby the MoF has agreed to assume all liabilities and risks arising from the Group's agreement with SAFE China. Further, this also includes a deposit of USD 500 million received from SAFE in June 2008 carrying interest at six months LIBOR plus 100 bps payable semi-annually. The outstanding balance of this deposit is USD 100 million as on June 30, 2013 (2012: USD 200 million). This deposit is the direct liability of the [SDP].’ 2. AidData has estimated the final maturity date of the loan to be June 2014 (based on the repayment schedule outlined in Staff Note 1).
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL BUDGET SUPPORT

# Title
China’s SAFE provides $500 million deposit loan to shore up Pakistan’s foreign exchange reserves in 2008

# Description
In June 2008, China’s State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) provided a $500 million deposit loan to State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) in order to shore up the country’s foreign exchange reserves. The loan carried the following terms: a 6-year (estimated) maturity and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (3.104% in June 2008) plus a 1% margin. The loan was repayable semi-annually. According to the SBP, the outstanding balance of this loan was $300 million on June 30, 2011, $200 million on June 30, 2012, and $100 million on June 30, 2013.
justification: Project involves financial support without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Deposit loan to shore up foreign exchange reserves, no environmental or energy-related components mentioned

title: Bank of China provides $300 million loan to shore up the Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves in 2008
description: In 2008, Bank of China provided a $300 million deposit loan to State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) in order to shore up the country’s foreign exchange reserves. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.
staff_comments: 1. According to the State Bank of Pakistan Annual Report 2007-2008, ‘[a]t the end of FY08, the stock of Bank of China (BOC) deposits reached US$ 900 million, with 80.0 percent growth over the last year stock. Actually, foreign liabilities on account of BOC increased by US$ 500 in FY08, partially offset by US$ 100 million debt repayment in the first quarter of FY08.’

title: Chinese Embassy to Pakistan donates materials to Lok Virsa Museum of Islamabad Pakistan
description: On 13 March 2008, the Chinese Embassy donated a Stage Subtitler, a 16 mm film projector and 477 Chinese film archives to the Ethnology Museum of Lok Virsa of Islamabad. The equipment was presented by Chinese Ambassador, Lou Zhaohui and Cultural Councillor of Chinese Embassy, Shan Baoxiang to the Executive Director of Lok Virsa Uxi Mufti, while Secretary, Ministry of Culture, Shahid Rafi was also present on the occasion.

title: China Eximbank provides $327.74 million preferential buyer’s credit for Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project (Linked to Project ID#39030 and #72395)
description: On January 18, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $327,740,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2008) 1 TOTAL NO. (41) and ID#320080001] for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a 12 year maturity, a 3% interest rate, and unknown grace period.   This project, which is also known as the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Upgrade Project, involved the upgrading of a 335 km segment of the Karakoram Highway runs from Raikot to Khunjerab. This segment was widened from 10 to 30 meters, making it suitable for heavy and long vehicles and allowing it to remain functional throughout the year. The project also involved the construction of 32 new bridges and rehabilitate 27 existing bridges. Its total cost was $491 million.   China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) and the Pakistan National Highway Authority (NHA) were responsible for implementation of the project. National Engineering Services Pakistan (Nespak) served as a consultant for the project.  A groundbreaking ceremony was held on February 16, 2008. Construction began on August 1, 2008. The project was successfully completed on November 30, 2013. The road work was designed and constructed in accordance with China’s three-level highway standard. Final inspection of the project was was carried out by NHA's Inspection Wing.  There are some indications that the China Eximbank buyer’s credit loan for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. On or around July 1, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under the buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. Then, on November 19, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed another debt suspension agreement [No. DSSI2021PHASE1-036]. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under the buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. Then, on or around July 1, 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed another debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021 under the buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. The debt service suspension (rescheduling) from July 2020-December 2020 is captured via Project ID#96254. The debt service suspension (rescheduling) from January 2021-June 2021 is captured via Project ID#96251. The debt service suspension (rescheduling) from July 2021-December 2021 is captured via Project ID#96253.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 喀喇昆仑公路改扩建项目 or 喀喇昆仑公路（简称KKH). 2. Some ancillary works were also undertaken by CRBC to realign the highway due to a landslide that happened in 2010. 3. For details on the China Eximbank-financed realignment work of the Karakarom Highway, see Project ID#39030 and #72395. 4. Note that the upgrading and realignment works on the road are jointly called the Phase-I project of KKH Highway.5. The November 2020 debt suspension agreement [No. DSSI2021PHASE1-040] can be accessed in it entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/xzpw6c8dp9e2lrt/13.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20BC%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides $327.74 million preferential buyer’s credit for Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project (Linked to Project ID#39030 and #72395)

# Description
On January 18, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $327,740,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2008) 1 TOTAL NO. (41) and ID#320080001] for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a 12 year maturity, a 3% interest rate, and unknown grace period.   This project, which is also known as the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Upgrade Project, involved the upgrading of a 335 km segment of the Karakoram Highway runs from Raikot to Khunjerab. This segment was widened from 10 to 30 meters, making it suitable for heavy and long vehicles and allowing it to remain functional throughout the year. The project also involved the construction of 32 new bridges and rehabilitate 27 existing bridges. Its total cost was $491 million.   China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) and the Pakistan National Highway Authority (NHA) were responsible for implementation of the project. National Engineering Services Pakistan (Nespak) served as a consultant for the project.  A groundbreaking ceremony was held on February 16, 2008. Construction began on August 1, 2008. On or around July 1, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under the buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. Then, on November 19, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed another debt suspension agreement [No. DSSI2021PHASE1-036]. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under the buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021 under the buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project.
